Business, he pointed out Sunday night, is pessimistic, and he found it hard to know why. must be the only man in Australia who does thatnot know the reasons why. I refer to another leading article in the 'Mail Times' which is a newspaper pubhshed in my electorate of Wimmera. I cannot read the whole article but I shall one paragraph. It is a very good article. It Budget was a national tragedy. It was aimed, directly at the destruction of private enterprise. It was product of socialist theorists who are determined to primary industry to a peasant state and the business world to hopelessness. graspAnother article which appeared in the 'Mail on Monday, 30 September, is very because it is pretty factual. It reads: The Government may as well tell everyone to waste their Why save? There is no merit in thrift or in provision the future. Booze, gamble, spend any way you like, but make sure you spend-that is the message behind the deafter it cision to tax savings. from anything else which has been said all asover Australia and which has appeared in the various media, surely these articles should the Government to the fact that all is not well. Maybe it was articles such as these which made the Government, or the Caucus, make decisions. I am rather interested to note in 'Daily Mirror' that the Prime Minister is now starting to come the bluff and referring to calling an election. This follows a statement made by the Minister fbr Manufacturing Indussup-try (Mr Enderby) some 10 days ago in which he whensaid that the Labor Party is fundamentally ask:democratic. Yet the Prime Minister is threatento call an election if the Senate rejects any Letpart of the Budget. Mr Deputy Speaker, can you is me, or can anyone on the Government side thetell me, the difference between the Senate, a democratically elected body of people, rejecting something and the Caucus rejecting Cabinet decosts. cisions? Mr Mulder-What is the difference?

Speaker: Mr KING
Title: TARCOOLA TO ALICE SPRINGS
text: What is the difference? Come on, tell us. The honourable member is not game tell us. Like the honourable member for Petrie (Mr Hodges), I beheve that there is a httle bit good in the Budget. It is pretty hard to find.As think the honourable member for Riverina (Mr Sullivan) interjected, it would take 3 seconds explain it ah. I think he is pretty right The get contains a lot of things which will catch the public sympathy. In other words, they will catch pubhc support. I mention such things as the extraducers, funds to be paid in health benefits, to nursing homes, in social security payments and for education. AU of these payments are very beneficial to the recipients. But I note, as do many other people, the backing away by the Government from an earher promise to ease further the meansbut test. This will be a bitter blow to many people who were depending on this promise being carindustries. ried out. Under the heading of Aboriginal Advancement we see a very big increase, and many people will go along with this. WhUe I not want to discredit this particular cause I queryprevious the extra expenditure of some $65m, because know that all the money aUocated in the Budget was not spent; yet the commitment on this occasion is going to go up by $65m. Perhaps this is the reason we saw a change in the portfoliosuperphosphate of the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs. Perhaps the previous Minister overspent I mention the Defence Service Homes maximum loan, which is to rise from $12,000 to $15,000. Very good, keeping pace with inflation. Perhaps I should say it is keeping pace, but it is coming near Here again there is a discrimination in interest rates. One rate is 3% per cent remainder it is 7 W per cent. These are some of the issues in the Budget thatwhere. may be partly favourable. However, there are many others that will carry the burden of some these issues that it is not funny. For instance, there is the Post Office, and I think the honourtoday, able member for Petrie (Mr Hodges) mentioned this. Why do we expect to see a profit in the Post Office of some $55m? There are 2 reasons. One that there is an increase in charges. These increased charges have now been implemented and the Government was very much on the baUmember on that one. Secondly, there is a slowing down capital expenditure. There has been no increase in the aUocation of capital expenditure, which means in theory, and no doubt in practice, that there is going to be a reduction of some 20 per cent in capital expenditure caused by increased It is almost an insult to include in the Budget Papers assistance for agricultural and pastoral industries. The totalfigureshows a contribution of $311m, but a close examination of one item alone proves how this misleads the pubto Uc. For the wool industry there is shown an amount well above the actual. The levy placed ofon growers under the new reserve price plan has Ibeen included, as well as the other levy for research and promotion. These levies are both to included as Government expenditure. This is not Bud-Government expenditure but is a contribution made by the growers themselves. So if this figure is deleted the amount allocated to primary prodespite inflation and despite lower export returns, is ever so much less than it was last year. If one examines Table 2, section C, of the Budget Papers one sees that an expenditure of $31 lm has been allocated to primary industries, if one looks at Table 4 under Receipts one finds $163m wiU be forthcoming from primary So instead of having a total expenditure of $31 lm, which has been quoted by members of the Government, the expenditure is only do$148m. If this is compared with expenditure in years based on the same formula, and I we can go back as far as 1968-69, the amounts were last $200m, then $352m, $192m, $312m, $204m, $232m and this year $ 148m. I might add that the $148m includes some $46m for a bounty that in theory is going to expire on 31 December. We do not know what the final decision is going to be. Despite a record low price for wool, despite the fact that we canit is not sell beef, mutton and lamb on the export not market and that what we do sell is at almost to it.record low prices, the Government has cut expenditure for primary industries to the lowest and for the level since 1968. Mr Hewson-And offered no support anyso Mr KING-It certainly has not offered any ofsupport anywhere. So if one compares the allocations made by the Labor Government of plus the estimate for this year, allowing for a 15 per cent inflation, they are equal to only about 50 per cent of the allocations of the preisvious Government. Primary producers by their actions on 18 May showed their feelings by displacing 4 Labor Party members, including the for Riverina, and almost displacing two inor three more. Given a few extra votes the Opposition would have had another 3 members. The Minister for Agriculture (Senator Wriedt) said recently that farm exports would be only marginaUy lower than last year. I do not know where he got his figures from, but that was his statement. I would not be permitted to use in this House the words expressed by many primary producers throughout the length and breadth of Australia. To my mind, this is a shocking Budget; it sneaky Budget and a most discriminating one. tries to win support, irrespective of the long factors. It belts into any form of incentive. Indisputably it is an inflationary Budget. Any individual who tries to expand, to develop and produce more, which in turn helps to reduce costs, is discouraged. I agree with my Leader (Mr Anthony) when he says that Australia's standard of living will fall if agricultural production falls. In other words, what he is saying is that an affluent primary industry makes an affluent Australia. Australia is basicaUy a food producing nation. There is no country in the exports a higher proportion of its production than Australia does. When I hear members of the Labor Party talking I am absolutely certain they do not appreciate this point. There are few commodities that fluctuate in price more than foodstuffs, because they are subject to. seasonal conditions, not only in Austraha but throughout the world. There is certainly a great deal of truth in the old cUche about the swing of the pendusuch lum. A few years ago there was a surplus of grain throughout the world and very low prices as a result; today there is a shortage, hence high prices. Last year there was a shortage of beef, creating high prices; today we have a glut, hence low prices. These principles apply to many items - sugar , dairy products and a host of others. These are but some of the reasons why, in the broad, primary producers want some form stabUisation to cover their various commodities. True, stabUisation means a contribution when times are good and assistance when things are not so good. It appears that there are many tax is appUed. people who forget this principle. Wheat growers are certainly not very happy with the Governmoved ment's new scheme because it is not a true isation scheme, as my colleague the honourable member for Darling Downs (Mr MCVeigh), mythe self and others pointed out during the recent bate on this issue. Mr MCVeigh-The farmers give the wheat to the Austrahan consumer.

Speaker: Mr KING
Title: TARCOOLA TO ALICE SPRINGS
text: Of course they almost give it to consumer, at approximately half ting something hke $100m per year. What this new scheme does is to cut off the peaks, both and down, and if we run into a lengthy period rough times it will do nothing to assist the producers. It follows the price up and it will follow the price down. Primary industries are not alone. They have sinular problems to many secondary industries. That is why we see all the leading articles and front page articles about the problems of is a industry at the present time, all caused by It Government decisions on inflation and reduced term tariffs and this sort of thing. However, the Government must like primary industries because it has a buUd up of reserves to counter the weak periods. Little thought is given when a purchaser has to pay more. Sometimes they forget that the retaUer has to pay a little extra too. Some of the proposals such as the capital gains tax are going to discourage development, not encourage it. The removal of taxation incentives in the last Budget also helped to cripple the development and expansion of many of our industries, both world that primary and secondary. If inflation continues at the present rate or at even half of the present rate for the next 10 or 20 years, I ask what is going to happen to our factories, our farms, our businesses on the death ofan owner or on his retirement or even if he just decides to sell or change to another business? The increased capital by virtue of inflation will be that half of it could be lost. If inflation were to run at 10 per cent a year for the next 10 years then the capital value of the property, everything else being equal, would be something Uke 250 per cent above the original value. That is at the rate of 10 per cent and not at the rate of 20 per cent or 20 per cent plus, which is the rate at which it is running today. I am taking the rate of 10 per cent. What type of capital tax would this attract over a period of time if 2 farmers or 2 of businessmen were to decide to change their farms or businesses, which is not uncommon? They would both finish up actually owning only a portion of the farm or business after the capital I support wholeheartedly the amendment by the Leader of the Opposition (Mr stabUSnedden). Some very worthwhUe contributions have been made from this side of the chamber on weaknesses of this Budget. I think it was the dehonourable member for Griffith (Mr Donald Cameron) who made some comment about a chche that was being bandied around about the Prime Minister. It was:'Gough's going great'. I think one word should be added. I think it ought the to read something Uke this: ' Gough's going; price, contributhat's great'.

Speaker: Mr MULDER
Title: TARCOOLA TO ALICE SPRINGS
text: From all Opup position speakers today we have heard the same of record slowly repeating over and over again the words 'inflation' and 'unemployment'. The old communist can was kicked earlier by the honourable member for Petrie (Mr Hodges). We even had the melodramatic performance from the last speaker in the debate, the honourable member for Wimmera (Mr King), who threw newspapers in the air and repeated the same subjects of inflation and unemployment. I think he left out the communist can. Very few alternative proposals, if any, have been presented or even mentioned by the Opposition. The speech of the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Snedden) in support of his amendment was so moving and enlightening that the Leader of the House (Mr Daly) had to go around to the Opposition side of the chamber and wake up one of the Opposition members on the front bench. That shows the impact of the speech of the Leader of the Opposition. But no alternatives have been presented to the Budget proposals. In 1973 the Opposition began to feel the power of its control of the Senate while at the same time experiencing the frustration of the lack of control of the treasury benches in this House. Repeatedly the Opposition threatened to withhold Supply. If I am not mistaken the original threat was made by a member of this chamber, the right honourable member for Lowe (Mr MCMahon). Last week the same honourable member again made the same threat and again it was repeated by other speakers on the Opposition side of the chamber. They are now kicking the can and talking about holding another double dissolution. The Opposition partiesfirmlybeheve that they did not lose the 1972 election. Their Leader is still maintaining that he did not lose the 1974 election. They believe that they were born to lead and that no other party has this God-given right. The Opposition is determined to obstruct the legislation presented to the Parhament by a Government which was elected to office only 4 months ago. The people of Austraha elected the Austrahan Labor Party to office in 1972 because of its promises. They re-elected the same Party to office this year because of the positive action it has taken. Mr MCVeigh-The same promises.

Speaker: Mr MULDER
Title: TARCOOLA TO ALICE SPRINGS
text: But the people of Austraha saw more action taken in the short term in which the Australian Labor Party was in office than they saw in the 23 years in which the Liberal and Country Parties were in office. The Austrahan Labor Party was re-elected to office, even though honourable members opposite may not beheve that it won the election. I beheve that if another election were forced by the Opposition within the term of the present Parliament the people would re-elect the Labor Party to office because, as is obvious from this debate, no alternative proposals have been put forward by the makeshift Opposition. It has avoided putting forward alternative proposals right throughout this debate. Most of the Budgets brought down by the present Opposition when it was in government were given nicknames. I call to mind the 'mini' Budget and the wonderful 'horror' Budget. Honourable members opposite are proud of the Budgets that they brought down. They remember the Budgets of their days in office when people were put out of work. But in their days in office they never provided the people that they put out of work with a reasonable living allowance or a reasonable opportunity for retraining. They never looked after them. All they wanted to do was to have those people sacked and left out on a limb on the labour market in order to give themselves more power. With this Budget the Government is continuing along the same lines as the 1973 Budget. The field of education is again to be the main benefactor from this Budget. An amount of $240m was spent in 1973-74. It is proposed to spend $275m thisfinancialyear. In my electorate class rooms have been added to schools and there has been an upsurge in the spending on private and State schools. Teachers as well as parents can now see the reasons why these large amounts of money are being spent. Mr Sullivan-Will children have jobs if they leave school this year?

Speaker: Mr MULDER
Title: TARCOOLA TO ALICE SPRINGS
text: At least the children are getting a reasonable education. As a matter of fact those interested in tertiary education can now get more than the Opposition gave them when it was in office. They can get free tertiary education when they leave school. They could not do that when the Opposition was in office. Mr MCVeigh-They will be all dressed up when theyfinishwith nowhere to go.

Speaker: Mr MULDER
Title: TARCOOLA TO ALICE SPRINGS
text: But you never thought about that in 1961,1965 and 1971.

Speaker: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER
Title: TARCOOLA TO ALICE SPRINGS
text: Dr Jenkins)Order! I ask the honourable member for Evans to address his remarks to the Chair and the honourable member for Darling Downs to remain silent.

Speaker: Mr MULDER
Title: TARCOOLA TO ALICE SPRINGS
text: What amazes me is that $ll m more than the estimate for 1973-74 was spent but the shortfall in the outlays-the actual payments-fel l short of the Budget estimates by $24m. That was due to the problems experienced by the States in the carrying through of the construction stages of the new building programs approved on the recommendations of the Interim Committee for the Austrahan Schools Commission. There was also a shortfall in relation to coUeges of advanced education and the technical education program. Let us hear from those States to which this money is going as to why they cannot spend it. They say that they do not want to be directed. Yet we give them the money and they cannot even spend it. As I have said, this Budget is a continuation the 1973 Budget. The appropriation for the Department of Health has been increased from approximately $70m to $99m, for the Department ofHousing from $130m to $160m, for the Department of Social Security from $89m to $141m, for the Department of Transport from $242m to $260m and for the Department of Urban and Regional Development from $ l l m to $14m. In the outer western suburbs of Sydney it is proposed to engage in the construction of new hospitals, the provision of new transport facUities and the undertaking of urban and regional development projects. That is where this money is going to be spent and that is where the people who voted for the Australian Labor Party last May see it being spent. That is why I have said that it was the actions of the Government that resulted in it being re-elected to office in May of this year. The expenditure by the Government must mean work opportunities in and more money for the section of the community in which it is most needed. The buUding of schools, community centres, transport facilities and so on is a great source of money for that section of private try which is mainly engaged in such activities. I would rather see a new hospital constructed in my electorate than a multi-storey office block which more than likely would be only half filled. I would rather see the extra $4 a week which will bring the totaUy and permanently incapacitated pension rate up to $64.10 a week spent on such pensioners than in the form of subsidies for the group to which the Liberal-Country Party Government would have given it, that is, the primary producers. Money that has been given to support mothers and to aU other people receiving welfare benefits and who need that money is money well spent. Money which we are spending on hospitals, homes and transport systems goes to private enterprise to buUd these faciUties. vate enterprise will receive greater stimulus in the future through this action. Let me put to honourable members the legislation which it is proposed to implement in the coming year. There is a scheme for income tax deductions on house mortgage interest payments. Also, there is a scheme which provides for deductions for the maintenance of dependants who are not residing in Australia. There is also a proposal to change the estate duty law and to set up a board to hear applications for a release from the payment of duty in cases of severe hardship. We have a poUcy to continue to change theseMr Kelly-There are only the Minister and of yourself in the chamber now.

Speaker: Mr MULDER
Title: TARCOOLA TO ALICE SPRINGS
text: Honourable members opposite had 20 minutes in which to speak. We did not interrupt them when they were on their feet. There has been much opposition to the proposed surcharge on property income, that is unearned income which an individual receives from property. I believe that this sort of income should be subject to a higher rate of tax than income derived from personal exertion. One of my constituents brought 2 documents to me last week and one can see from their contents, to use an old Australian saying, how fair dinkum house or flat owners are. On 19 July an estate agent wrote a letter to my constituent in regard to rental increases. The estate agent said: We have been instructed to inform you that your rent is to be increased to $33 per week, as from the 15th August 1974. Would you please contact this office before the 15th August, 1974 to make arrangements to sign the necessary documents. A fee of $5 will be necessary to cover costs of stamp duty . . . Less than 3 months later another letter was written to my constituent also in respect of a rental indus- increase. The letter stated: Dear Sir, We have been instructed to inform you that your rent is to be increased by $2 perweek. This is $2 on the other increase. The letter continued: This rental increase is brought about by the recent taxauon surcharge in the Federal Budget, the owners advise that they cannot absorb charges of this type. A fee of $5 will also be necessary to cover the costs of stamp duty. The letter pointed out that the new rent would be $35. Many people in my electorate will be affected in this way. The constituent who raised this matter with me is a man of not independent Pri- means although he has never received a pension. This increase will affect him. I suppose that a pensioner in these circumstances might get some assistance but here we have a case in which a person who is renting a house in my electorate has been slugged for an additional $2 within 3 months of having his rent increased. The house owner should not put his increased level of tax on the rent bill. The honourable member for Petrie (Mr Hodges) commenced his speech by again bringing out the old red rag. However, later in his speech I thought he was speaking on the side of the Labor Party. Mr Kevin Cairns-Oh , no.

Speaker: Mr MULDER
Title: TARCOOLA TO ALICE SPRINGS
text: Yes . He quoted many of the will promises of the Prime Minister (Mr Whitlam) which we are fulfilling. Then he came to the doom cries. It was on this point I commenced my speech. We have heard doom cries from every speaker on the Opposition side during this degood bate. In fact I think that this fear is seeping through the Liberal Party. A friend of mine received a letter from the Liberal Party the other worry. day which was headed: 'Re: The Survival of the Liberal Party'. It stated: The Industrial, Business and Professional Communities are facing mounting financial problems and possible lapse-so is the Liberal Party. When we have this old record being played over and over that we are doomed, and when the threat of a double dissolution is held at the Government's head, from where will the people find confidence, where is the solidarity, how the Government continue when it is being faced with the threat of being thrown out of office every 3 months? As the honourable member for Blaxland (Mr Keating) said, this could happen. We are so finely divided that we could be in office one week, be thrown out the next and could throw the Opposition out the week after. From where does the confidence of the people come in these circumstances? Mr King-It is your Prime Minister who threatening us.

Speaker: Mr MULDER
Title: TARCOOLA TO ALICE SPRINGS
text: It is the Opposition. The ties Leader of the Opposition-you r aspiring Minister-go t up the other day and I beheve he said that he hoped there would be a double dissolution. He was thefirstto threaten it and many members of the Opposition have followed him with the same threat. This threat was also made by the honourable member for Petrie. The position is sitting on the other side of the and we are sitting on this side of the House cause of the 23 years in which no action was taken by the previous Government. I hope that this situation will continue to remind members the Opposition why they lost government. Yet the Opposition criticises the Government. Mr Nixon-Where are all your friends? You have cleared the House.

Speaker: Mr MULDER
Title: TARCOOLA TO ALICE SPRINGS
text: Well , well. Billy the blackfellow has come in now and starts chirping. The Minister for Services and Property (Mr Daly), who represents the electorate adjacent to mine, and I have had the pleasure of opening many social security offices. We have opened two lately. Also more people have been able to obtain legal aid in our electorates as a result of the Government's actions. A social security office also be opened in the electorate of the right honourable member for Lowe (Mr MCMahon). I do not know whether he considers that the establishment of these offices is a good or bad thing. But one sees that in every electorate something is happening for people in these electorates right and mostly for disadvantaged people, the people about whom members of the Opposition do not All that members of the Opposition have said so far is that confidence should be restored and colthat Government spending and income tax should be reduced. But one knows that income tax is stacked so much against the small man that members of the Opposition are only interested in looking after the bigger man. They are not worried about the small man, the average working man, when they say that the Government should can reduce income tax. It is only worried about the big man because the system is stacked against the Uttle man. The big man can make his lurks and perks out of the income tax system. The Opposition says that the Government should reduce Government spending from 35 per cent to 24 per we cent. But members of the Opposition have not said where they would reduce this spending. Do they want to cut out the building of new schools and tertiary institutions or reduce expenditure on urban development? Do they want to reduce the is level of pensions? They should say what they want cut out. But they will not. All that the Paron the other side want is new subsidies to be Prime put on to prop them up. Mr Sullivan-No , return the concessions-that is what we want.

Speaker: Mr MULDER
Title: TARCOOLA TO ALICE SPRINGS
text: That is all you want-conces sions or subsidies, it does not matter. I will finish Optonight on the point wefinishedon last week House when honourable members spoke about Caucus. beHonourable members opposite have endeavoured to make Caucus a dirty word not only in this House but throughout Australia. A Caucus of meeting is a democratic meeting of all those who have been elected both to the Senate and to the House of Representatives and each member has an equal say. It is democratic. We hear people such as the honourable member for Petrie (Mr Hodges) talking in this place about the right, the left and communism. It is a pity that we do not open our meeting one day just to let in those who sit opposite. They worry more about our Caucus than they do about their own. What democracy do they have within their Caucus? (Quorum formed)

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Title: TARCOOLA TO ALICE SPRINGS
text: Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

Speaker: Mr KILLEN
Title: TARCOOLA TO ALICE SPRINGS
text: The honourit able member for Evans (Mr Mulder) made a friend boisterous speech in support of the Budget. I sorry that he was not received with boisterous support. In fact, I think at one stage he reached the point where he was supported by the Minisadjusted. ter for Science (Mr Morrison) and nobody else. One could hardly say that Government members were collapsing with excitement. The honourday, able member made one observation which I am shutting down. bound to tell you, Mr Speaker, in simple candour having known you for nearly one-fifth of a century, appeals to me immensely. He said: ' I would like to throw open the doors, the portals of the Caucus meeting so you could all come in'. Mr Speaker, I hope you will forgive and understand Tasmanians. my presumption but I present myself as the guest speaker tomorrow.

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Title: TARCOOLA TO ALICE SPRINGS
text: I do not think you would get correction. ago.

Speaker: Mr KILLEN
Title: TARCOOLA TO ALICE SPRINGS
text: Whose feelings would be lacerated is open to some doubt, nevertheless it would be an interesting exchange. I turn immediately to my principal adversary, the Prime Minister (Mr Whitlam). I welcome him back to Austraha. I am dehghted that he arrived truth? back in one piece. I pressed upon him before he left the perils of his journey bearing in mind such distinguished people as Milton Obote and Kwame Nkrumah. It was a matter of some vexdoes ation to me that his name would be added to that hst.

Speaker: Mr COHEN
Title: TARCOOLA TO ALICE SPRINGS
text: The honourable members behind you do not know who they are.

Speaker: Mr KILLEN
Title: TARCOOLA TO ALICE SPRINGS
text: No subtlety the honourable member for Robertson but he is a conspicuous exception as far as the Governit ment benches are concerned. Anyhow, the Prime Minister did arrive back. I am bound to say that congratulate him upon a massive sense of urMinister banity.

Speaker: Mr MORRISON
Title: TARCOOLA TO ALICE SPRINGS
text: Ur-ban-ity .

Speaker: Mr KILLEN
Title: TARCOOLA TO ALICE SPRINGS
text: Oh , here is Australia's own Oxford graduate, what would happen if I were to seek to correct the Minister's solecisms? He is going to say so-lecisms. He has gone that close to flying solo it does not matter. Urbane-ity or urban-ity, wherever my friend wants to put the emphasis on the consonontal pronunciation. I put the adenoids to one side. I am deUghted that the Prime Minister is back. I do congratulate him. He arrived back. We have 160,000 unemployed. Mr Gorton-More than that.

Speaker: Mr KILLEN
Title: TARCOOLA TO ALICE SPRINGS
text: I am indebted to the right honourable member for Higgins for saying that is more than that, but my right honourable knows that I err constantly on the side of am conservatism. The Prime Minister arrived back at a time when we have 170,000 people out of work, seasonally adjusted or any other way We have inflation raging at 20 per cent. We have hundreds of thousands of Ufe insurance holders seeing their investment dwindle day by month by month. We have industries galore

Speaker: Mr COHEN
Title: TARCOOLA TO ALICE SPRINGS
text: We have got two anyway.

Speaker: Mr KILLEN
Title: TARCOOLA TO ALICE SPRINGS
text: I beg your pardon. If you say that in the textile industry only 2 factories are shutting down then I suggest you tell that to the

Speaker: Mr HURFORD
Title: TARCOOLA TO ALICE SPRINGS
text: He did not say that.

Speaker: Mr KILLEN
Title: TARCOOLA TO ALICE SPRINGS
text: I am indebted to you for your

Speaker: Mr HURFORD
Title: TARCOOLA TO ALICE SPRINGS
text: You said 'industries'.

Speaker: Mr KILLEN
Title: TARCOOLA TO ALICE SPRINGS
text: Well , industry after industry.

Speaker: Mr HURFORD
Title: TARCOOLA TO ALICE SPRINGS
text: B e accurate.

Speaker: Mr KILLEN
Title: TARCOOLA TO ALICE SPRINGS
text: Since when has the honourable member for Adelaide been concerned with the

Speaker: Mr HURFORD
Title: TARCOOLA TO ALICE SPRINGS
text: Eve r since I came into this place.

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Title: TARCOOLA TO ALICE SPRINGS
text: Order! Just being in his seat not give the honourable member the right to interject. The honourable member for Robertson also will cease interjecting.

Speaker: Mr COHEN
Title: TARCOOLA TO ALICE SPRINGS
text: I did not say anything.

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Title: TARCOOLA TO ALICE SPRINGS
text: I know you did not then but has ever escaped you did earUer.

Speaker: Mr KILLEN
Title: TARCOOLA TO ALICE SPRINGS
text: Obviously, Mr Speaker, he had very much in contemplation. We have thousands of people being flung out of work-the I whole edifice of disaster. What does the Prime say? He says: 'All is well'. I must hand it to him. He would put out of business a bishop preaching a sermon wearing a clerical collar, a pair of gaiters and nothing else. Mr Martin-They do not wear them.

Speaker: Mr KILLEN
Title: TARCOOLA TO ALICE SPRINGS
text: I am delighted to know that the honourable gentleman at least has some ecclesiastical knowledge. I am sorry I cannot extend the compliment. There is an extraordinary state of affairs. Is this the Labor Party's attitude towards contemporary Australia-170,00 0 or 180,000 people out of work? Let me remind honourable members opposite of the heroic words of their leader when he sat on this side of the House back in 1972. It is not as though I am foraging back into ancient history. This was in 1972. This was before, as a result of some aberration on the part of the Australian people, he became the Prime Minister. Listen to this and then go home and meditate. He said: There is the enduring task of reducing inflauon. Party's policies are totally committed to full employment and reducing inflation; This was said in February 1972. He said: 'My Party's policies are totaUy committed towards reducing inflauon and committed to fuU employvate ment' Is the honourable member for Port Adelaide (Mr Young) or any other honourable says: gendeman who may be minded to interrupt more going to say to those who today find themselves out of work, seasonaUy adjusted, that this is splendid vindication of the declaration the Prime Minister gave in February 1972? The Prime economy, Minister, just to Ulustrate what splendid ency he has, came to the Premiers Conference in June of this year and made another statement. Listen to the dulcet tones. The language is perb. He said: In order to help break inflationary expectations, now slow the rate of increase in Government spending. phasing down or deferment of some expenditure plans occur. Is there any ambiguity about that? No person aU with 2 wits to rub together-by joves, it fine down a few honourable members opposite- ParUamentwould have any doubt about that. He said that Government expenditure was to decrease. What is the sorry record? OveraU there is to be a total increase in Government expenditure of 32.4 per cent.

Speaker: Mr COHEN
Title: TARCOOLA TO ALICE SPRINGS
text: Hear , hear!

Speaker: Mr KILLEN
Title: TARCOOLA TO ALICE SPRINGS
text: The honourable member for acerbity Robertson approves of it. I ask the honourable gentleman, in terms of simple logic, how does he settle the Prime Minister's declaration to the Premiers Conference that there must be a reducnot tion in Government expenditure with a Governwhat ment increase in expenditure of 32.4 per cent? You can run through one department after the other in order to see where the increase has place. It was left to the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Snedden) and, if I may say so with respect, to a conspicuously thoughtful speech made by the honourable member for LUley (Mr Kevin Cairns) a week or so ago to point to the real earnest of the Government's intention. It is to be found in one phrase of the Budget Speech by the Treasurer (Mr Crean). The Treasurer talked about the fact that the private sector is now enjoying subdued conditions. 'Enjoying' may be a rather ornate description of it, but there are subdued conditions as far as the private sector is concerned. The honourable gentleman then went on to say: 'This then is the opportune time to transfer emphasis to the pubUc sector.' I only hope that the people of Australia are under no doubt whatsoever as to what is meant My by that declaration. Seventy-five per cent of the Australian wage and salary earners owe their livelihood to the private sector. The enjoyment, the integrity and the existence of 75 per cent of famiUes in this country are to be found in the prisector. Here it is, a plain declaration of war by the Government upon the private sector. It 'Let us disturb the private sector. Let us put emphasis upon the public sector'. The simple truth of life is that nothing in this world can a be had for nothing save measles. When people talk about seeking to bring back stabUity to our is this the sort of nonsense that will enconsistcourage them? Are the 170,000 or 180,000 people out of work today, in a virtual depression state, going to be encouraged and roused by the sufact that the Government has said: 'We want to extinguish further the activity of the private secwe must tor'? To use the phrase coined by my friend, the Some honourable member for LUley: 'You will be must mighty cool in Clyde Cameron's pool'. Great stuff, is it not? But I fear that we all make a misat take in attributing to the gentlemen who line, would decorate, occupy the front bench of this Mr O'Keefe-Where are they? There are not many there.

Speaker: Mr KILLEN
Title: TARCOOLA TO ALICE SPRINGS
text: They are probably out, if not speculating on the future, hoping for the best. A few of them have wandered into the chamber, albeit by accident. I do not want to resort to any of language at all to describe them because it upsets me. I reproach myself for the absence of charity in having described their activities as the activities of bunglers because that is true. The simple truth of the matter is that this Government has determined upon is not merely to create in Australia a state of bungle by accident; it has set about creating a state of taken economic crisis by purpose. Let no person be under any misapprehension about this. I wish to say something about the Minister for Overseas Trade (Dr JF CAIRNS). I regret, and I apologise for it, attacking him in his absence. Mr Martin-You doriotreally.

Speaker: Mr KILLEN
Title: TARCOOLA TO ALICE SPRINGS
text: Yes , I do. Never in my time of nearly 20 years in this Parliament have I ship, attacked any person unless I some notice ofit. Mr Martin-U p till now.

Speaker: Mr KILLEN
Title: TARCOOLA TO ALICE SPRINGS
text: U p until today. I make an exception. I have in my hand a book entitled 'The Quiet Revolution' written by James Ford Cairns, the Minister for Overseas Trade. It should be made compulsory reading for people of this country. I take at random, believe it or not, a couple of excerpts from my friends sis Mr book. Listen to this. Mr MCKenzie-Try page 44.

Speaker: Mr KILLEN
Title: TARCOOLA TO ALICE SPRINGS
text: Believ e it or not, I am inclined to the view that the honourable member for Diavote mond Valley is an unconscious victim of what is going on. Mr MCKenzie-How about page 44?

Speaker: Mr KILLEN
Title: TARCOOLA TO ALICE SPRINGS
text: No . I will go to page 133 for they openers. It states: In a very signincant sense Labor cannot gain power simply by winning an election. The honourable gentleman argues, in advance that proposition, this: Change is slow and the revolution is quiet. Progress have to be worked hard forI thought the language there was appalling, put that to one side. It goes on: and within the limits that today's realities provide.

Speaker: Mr GRAHAM
Title: TARCOOLA TO ALICE SPRINGS
text: He did not learn any grammar.

Speaker: Mr KILLEN
Title: TARCOOLA TO ALICE SPRINGS
text: Split infinitives do not matter all. What the Minister for Overseas Trade has determined upon is to seek to change the entire system in Australia. Do honourable members know what the central thesis of that book is? It that you must destroy tLe existing free enterprise system in Australia. The Treasurer hand made the declaration that we must, in a state of subdued conditions, transfer emphasis from the private to the public sector. Whether personal the Treasurer was conscious of the thesis propounded by the Minister for Overseas cannot vouch for, but there can be no doubting whatsoever what the Minister for Overseas Trade has in mind. By no means is he alone. Mr MCKenzie-Hear, hear!

Speaker: Mr KILLEN
Title: TARCOOLA TO ALICE SPRINGS
text: Listen to the 'hear hear' from the honourable member for Diamond Valley. Let us put on our next election poster that he agrees with it. The Federal President of the honourable gentleman's Party, Mr HAWKE - at least I am on ringing terms with him-sai d this: This capitalist system, this free enterprise, private ownerprofit maximisation system, is not my system, it is not the system of the trade union movement, it's not the system have given him of the Labor Party.

Speaker: Mr COHEN
Title: TARCOOLA TO ALICE SPRINGS
text: Hear , hear.

Speaker: Mr KILLEN
Title: TARCOOLA TO ALICE SPRINGS
text: I am dehghted tofindthat the flute obbligato-the honourable member for Robertson-agree s with that proposition also. This is the declaration to destroy the system-to the seek to destroy it by wrecking it. MCKenzie-That is an unwarranted analyof the argument.

Speaker: Mr KILLEN
Title: TARCOOLA TO ALICE SPRINGS
text: I hope the two of you will get together and try to sort it out because the Minister for Overseas Trade, whom I understand you for with a consistency to be admired, has put it plainly on the line that the system must be changed. Instead of declaring to the Austrahan people that they propose to destroy the system Kampf' have gone about it. This book is the 'Mein of Fabius Cunctator-the Minister for Overseas Trade-wh o seeks to destroy Hannibal, at all the great emperor. We are faced with that simple realisation. I hope that the House will come to a of corporate understanding that whatever may have been done in this Budget, it is a Budget will which has been subjected to thefinalscrutiny of Caucus, an act probably unrivalled in the history but of the Anglo Saxon world. The Government has introduced a Budget and a bunch of self-elected, self-appointed committees has rambled around having a look to see where they canfixthings up. I say to the Parhament, and I hope to the Ausat trahan people, that this Budget is a design, marked by high purpose, to destroy this country. But the people of this country have sufficient command of enterprise, of wit and of courage is and if they can be given the opportunity they will sweep the Government to where it deserves to on the one go-to oblivion.

Speaker: Mr HURFORD
Title: TARCOOLA TO ALICE SPRINGS
text: I wish to make a explanation. Trade I Mr SPEAKER-Does the honourable member claim to have been misrepresented?

Speaker: Mr HURFORD
Title: TARCOOLA TO ALICE SPRINGS
text: During the course of his contribution to this debate-that is about all I can call it-the honourable member for Moreton (Mr Killen) asked the rhetorical question: When was the member for Adelaide ever interested in the truth? I take exception to that remark. I consider it is up to the honourable member to state whenever I have not been interested in the truth. I believe that statement of his was as hoUow as the rest ofhis speech.

Speaker: Mr DALY
Title: TARCOOLA TO ALICE SPRINGS
text: The honourable member for Moreton (Mr KUlen) was not at his best tonight. No doubt his remarks were prompted by the remarkable changes in Liberal poUcy which were announced last weekend. I notice from a report in the 'Sun' of 14 October that the Liberal Party has decided that God's name is now to be dropped from its pohcy. This is probably because Mr Snedden is leading the Party. The article said that God has been deleted from the new Liberal Party pohcy platform. He was mentioned in a preamble to the Party's former platform, which stated: The Liberal Party of Australia presents this platform program for a people whose highest ideals are inspired by belief in God. The Press article stated: A senior Liberal Party spokesman said yesterday that deletion of the preamble aid not necessarily mean that Liberal Party members no longer believed in God. AVhat has happened to the former Prime Minister, the right honourable member for Lowe (Mr MCMahon) who said he prayed to God each night for success? No doubt the results of the last election detennined that God should be dropped from the Liberal Party platform. Let us examine other proposed changes in that platform. The Liberal Party is looking for a new anthem. According to a Press report the Liberal Party said that 'God Save the Queen' should be used only for regal and vice-regal occasions and that another anthem should be promoted for other times. I wonder what the honourable member of Mackellar (Mr Wentworth) thinks of this matter. He made an inspiring address on an adjournment debate or during a discussion on a matter of pubhc importance arguing for the retention of 'God Save the Queen'. This was after a census throughout Australia showed that the people wanted theh own national anthem. Is it any wonder with the Liberal Party turning away from God and the Queen that the honourable member for Moreton should be moved to say what he said tonight? I noticed in the 'Sydney Morning Herald' of yesterday's date that an article in respect of the Liberal Party conference last weekend stated: The council finally laid to rest the ghost of Mr Gorton's 'sensualism'. My heavens, what could we expect from a government comprised of honourable members opposite? I also have a letter dated 11 September 1974 addressed to a person Uving in Stanmore from the Western MetropoUtan Region of the Liberal Party of Australia New South Wales Division. It reads: Dear Sir, Re: The Survival of the Liberal Pany The Industrial, Business and Professional Communides are facing mounting nnancial problems and possible collapse-so is the Liberal Party. Frankly, the stark position of the Liberal Pany is that it must raise $5,000 within the Western Metropolitan Region in conjunction with similar fund raising efforts through N.S.W. or collapse. We have been given just ten weeks to raise this amount. Will you help with an immediate donation? Fancy asking anybody to make a donation to help the Liberal Party. The letter continues: Cheques should be made payable to the Liberal Pany, Metropolitan Region, and forwarded to the Hon. Treasurer, as a Mr Frank Gumbley. Either complete the enclosed Bankers Order and return it to us, or let us have your commitment for an annual donation so that we can plan our future campaigns in an orderly and efficient manner to the best political effect, knowing in advance the amounts available to us for these purposes. A business-reply envelope is enclosed for your convenience.

Speaker: Mr DALY
Title: TARCOOLA TO ALICE SPRINGS
text: The honourable member for Kooyong interjects. He spends aU his money backing LeUani. He does not have money for Party funds so wants to make it from punting. I give him the good oU. LeUani has more chance of winning the Caulfield and Melbourne Cups than his Party has of winning the next Federal election. Why should the honourable member for Moreton not be worried? I also have an appUcation form that is to accompany donations to the Liberal Party. Is it any wonder that tonight the honourable member for Moreton plucked figures out of the air? He referred to 160,000 or 170,000 unemployed. A lawyer should not do these things; he should be factual. I advise the honourable member for Moreton to stick to the small debts court because it is much more simple. If he gets into the big time he will reaUse it takes brains to succeed. WhUst I may increase his small debts customers tomght, he will do better from them than he will do in the widerfield.Tonight he used extravagant statements about the Government's misdoings, but whatever those opposite say, we have won 2 elections in 18 months and they were lucky to win 2 elections in 6 years. This Government stands endorsed on 2 occasions by the people of Australia as the only people fit to govern this nation. Irrespective of what might be said by those opposite we have given to the people of Australia firm and sound government. How can any self-respecting person support a party that gives away God and gives away the national anthem? My godfather, members opposite are supposed to be loyalists. They claim also to have laid the ghost of sensualism. It is frightening to think that they might ever be in office. Having said so much, perhaps I should conclude by saying that fortunately for the people of Austraha the only Partyfitto govern Australia is in government. Its pohcies are sound and just. Irrespective of what might be said by those opposite it cannot be denied that in 23 months we have done more than they did in 23 years. I know that hurts, but it is the truth and I accordingly record it for the people of Australia to know. Debate interrupted.

Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: I think the judge House today has been treated for about the fourth time to a reply by the Leader of the House (Mr Daly) on rninerals and petroleum matters. We have heard the same speech from the same dear old fellow with the same humour, as corny

Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: Order! The honourable and Demember is out of order. In an adjournment debate an honourable member cannot refer to any debate that has taken place during this session.

Speaker: Mr GILES
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: Mr Speaker, the facts of the petroleum matter-this has nothing to do with the Bill that was before the House today-ar e as follows: Beach Petroleum, an Australian owned company, was forced by the policies of this Government to go looking for petroleum in New Zealand and Turkey. Genoa Oil and Hartog OU were forced by the policies of this Government to go looking for oil in the United States and Canada. Timor OU Ltd was forced to search, aptly enough, in Timor. Hartog OU with the Philips company has been forced to search for oU in Indonesia. International OU Exploration, Australian company, has been forced to search for oU in Indonesia. Broken HU1 Proindiprietary Co. Ltd has been searching for oU in for Malaya and the China Sea. Associated Ausbeen traUan Resources which runs the Roma area natural gas operation has been forced to search defor oU in the North Sea in the PenzoU Group. what Southern Pacific Petroleum, another Australian company, has been forced to search for oil outthis nation and in the North Sea area. What it is for this Government from time to the time to suggest that our side of the Parliament stands for compames that are not Australian searching for oU. If that is not bad enough, let us look at some of Parliament the statements by members of the Government over the last 6 months. I hope people will find some interest in this. The Minister for Social Security (Mr Hayden) said: 'This Government is presiding over the destruction of the Australian That is good clean stuff. I congratulate him on his statement. If we look a little further we see that on unemployment Mr Hawke said: 'This Government cannot suffer any unemployment'. The Treasurer, (Mr Crean), said in July this year: 'There will not be large scale unemployment during the next 6 months'. In any nation other than Australia a Minister would resign having made that statement and found himself so wide of the facts. The Prime Minister (Mr Whitlam) during the last election campaign assured the Press that there would be no unemployment. I ask honourable members just to that sort of remark for what it is worth. During the election campaign the Prime Minister also said: 'We have reduced inflation to 9 per cent and faUing'. What credibUity does one give a man who made a statement Uke that only a few months ago? The Deputy Prime Minister (Dr F. Caims) just to make it better, said: 'The of inflauon is 8 per cent and falling'. That was the time of the last election. The honourable member for Casey (Mr Mathews) produced this probably the best statement of the lot by saying: 'Inflation has been reduced by 26 per cent since Christmas'. That statement too was made during the last election campaign. What credibUity these people have when they make those sorts statements? In the Government that we have today, where Caucus exercises control over an execuuve decision, every member of the Governdoes ment has to share responsibUity for those sorts remarks and the people of Austraha eventuaUy will judge them on the attitude they take in relathinking. tion to it. I continue a httle further. On 31 May the Treasurer said: 'Inflation is an unacceptable per cent'. What is it now? Twenty per cent, 25 per cent? Nobody knows; it is raging ahead well. The Prime Minister said to the Premiers: 'Prices wiU remain uniform'. During the last election campaign the Minister for Overseas Trade said: 'The situation is serious enough to warrant increased taxation on the rich' and specified a mark of $14,000 a year- a bench mark that is rather familiar to members of Uament. Mr Hawke said: 'Any inflation rate is intolerable'. The Prime Minister, in the middle niining. of aU this, promised tax reductions. This is the sorry situation that faces the nation at present. I say that this Government has totaUy lost direction. Government supporters are reacting exactly as one would expect them to react. They are coming doubtful about their leadership. They are wondering where they are going. In the meantime the people of Austraha are left on rock not knowing quite which way to go, not having enough funds in reserve to replenish, date or modernise plant so that this nation efficient. Furthermore, there is a disincentive against anybody who wants to work or use his capital to invest in the nation's interests. That basic thoughtranningthrough the community Yet today. I say that this Government is not doing by the nation. I am inspired by the honourable member for Moreton (Mr KUlen) who spoke a Uttle whUe ago. Surely to goodness we must some realism into governmental thinking. Let look at another sphere that interests areas such my own electorate. The Government has said: 'We will adopt retraining measures where there is unemployment and pay workers $85 a whUe they rettain'. Yet on the other hand omciai government statistics give grape growers as an J. operator cost, having invested in their own rate farms, the princely return of $45 a week. How at does the Government and how do people equate this sort of siUy thinking, these anomahes that Government has aUowed to intrude into the area? On the one hand the Government now is saying that it will restructure farms, and on the other hand it is saying that perhaps it will do introduce a superphosphate bounty but at a of minimum level to help those in need, the small farmers. What manner of Ulogical thought is this? Does the Government want viable farms or it not want viable farms? It just seems to me of that nobody in the Government knows where the blazes he is going. There is too much muddled If we do not watch out, anyone who has a viable industry in the country, tomorrow will be brought down to the doubtful stage of viabUity. Any body that should be phased out will 13 also be brought up to the stage of doubtful viabUity. This is the spirit of the similar coloured so Budget that this Government has introduced. It is a Budget of mediocrity, a Budget that does not give emphasis to encouraging people to work, a Budget that certainly does not encourage people to invest, which, to give one Ulustration, is being made quite plain by the state of the share market. Yet, on the other hand, the Government Parcomplains that Australians do not have the wish to invest in, shaU we say, risk enterprises such as The Minister for Minerals and Energy has said bein the past that the aim of the Government is to nationalise the minerals industry entirely. Has any body stopped to have a look at the Governa ment's phUosophy as spelled out in the booklet on smaU businesses? I presume that the honourupable member for Adelaide (Mr Hurford) and is many other people profess an interest in smaU businesses. Might I add that many mineral firms in Australia today- I read out the names of some is a of them a httle while ago-ar e smaU businesses. in this booklet are set out 2 principles which govern the Government's pohcy in relation to small businesses. Thefirstprinciple is stated as its job being that they should be helped by modern techniques to become viable, and the second principle is to the effect that it is to the comget munity's interest that those who wish to us innovate, those who wish to use their own expertas ise and their own energies should be supported. Where do we stand when we see such contradictions? Are there no smaU businesses by way of week Australian mineral companies? Are there no small businesses by way of Australian oil companies? I read out a while ago the names of eight of them which were all forced to search for oil outside this country. Where is the logic of it? There is no question about the fact that this Government's policies are a fatal muddle working to the detriment of the people of Australia.

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: Order! The honourable member's dme has expired.

Speaker: Dr KLUGMAN
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: It is a great pity that the honourable member for Angas (Mr Giles), as a relatively senior member of the Opposition, did not get a go in the Budget debate. He obviously had prepared a speech on the Budget and was forced to make it tonight during the adjournment debate. Before I get on to the main part of my remarks tonight, I would like to mention one matter. The honourable member for Angas was attacking us about inflation. I would like to give one example of what causes inflation. One of my constituents brought into me the invoices and accounts that he had received in relation to the purchase of an airconditioner unit. He went to one of the large stores in Parramatta and brought an air-conditioner unit which he intended to instal himself. He was charged $475. He ordered a General Electric unit. The General Electric unit was delivered to his place by the General Electric Co. The store had nothing more to do with it. He found inside that General Electric air-conditioner an invoice for $236.56, which is less than half the amount he was charged for it. In addition to that, he decided to buy a General Electric unit because he wanted an Australian made air-conditioner which could be fixed readily in the event of a breakdown. When he looked at it he found it was imported from Hong Kong. The main reason I rise tonight is to draw the attention of the House to some very dangerous tendencies that are developing inside the Liberal Party. I know that that Party has had a lot of publicity during the last weekend for becoming a trendy Party and for being with it, and so on. But 1 would like to draw the attention of the House to 2 things that have come to my notice, one very recently and one not so recently. The honourable member for Warringah (Mr MACKellar) was appointed as spokesman on immigration by the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Snedden). I would like to read to the House from the Immigration Control Association's publication called 'Viewpoint'. In that publication the Association expresses its gratitude for that appointment and says how keen it is and how pleased it is about the appointment of the honourable member for Warringah. The publication reads: Hearty congratulations to Michael MACKellar (MHR for Warringah). Later on the gentleman who writes this vicious, racist pubUcation, one Robert Clark, under the heading 'An Interesting Morning in Canberra', states: On a trip to Canberra with my wife and another member of the Immigration Control Association we dropped into the House ofRepresentatives to talk to a few of the members. I am sure they were all members from the other side of the House. The pubUcation continues: We spoke to a few MPs one of whom invited us to the Speaker's Gallery the following morning. While we sat there waiting for question ume Mr MACKellar to whom some of our members including myself and our other member who was with me had given solid election suppon in his fight against St John in the previous election . . . I think it is important to note that the honourable member for Warringah has been appointed to a position which is particularly sensitive to the propositions of the Immigration Control Association. I wish to refer also to the Parramatta 'Advertiser' of 9 October 1974 which carried an article headed 'Libs Special Guest'. The article appeared as a result of one of the handouts of the honourable member for Parramatta (Mr Ruddock). The article reads: Guest speaker at the meeting of the Parramatta branch of the Young Liberal Movement on Monday, 14 October, will be national director of the Australian League of Rights, Mr E. D. Butler. The meeting will be in Parramatta Business and Professional Men's Club, Marsden Street at 7.30 p.m. Parramatta Branch of the Young Liberal Movement is active in all matters affecting the welfare of young people in the western area.

Speaker: Dr KLUGMAN
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: No, with all due respect to the honourable member for Adelaide, I think the honourable member for Moreton (Mr Killen) has dissociated himself from Eric Butler, and so have other members of the Opposition, especiaUy members of the Austrahan Country Party. I now refer to the Australian Country Party's report circulated in July 1971 which makes reference to Eric Butler, the friend of the honourable member for Parramatta and the man that the honourable member for Parramatta invited to address the Young Liberals in the area to tell them what it is all about. The report gave a rundown on Eric Butler's career-hi s virulent anti-Semitism, his support for the Nazis, his attacks on the Australian war effort and his writing for 'The New Times'. The honourable member for Boothby (Mr MCLeay), of course, is a close friend of all those people and has always supported them. He is probably the person in House best known as a close supporter of the sortmany of views expressed by the League of Rights Australia. Mr MCLeay-That is a bitter attack.

Speaker: Dr KLUGMAN
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: I am sure that the honourdemocracy able member does not consider it a bitter attack. In its report the Australian Country Party Although described the League of Rights as having reputable and racist basis, which it is now trying to conceal; declared the disciples of social credit, which Butler advocates, as sheer fanatics; quoted some of his writings on the communist conme. spiracy, which it then categorises as 'the language of paranoia'; spoke of Butler's violent position to parliamentary government, catalogue of hates; and stated that there thing breathtaking about lunacy on this scale. This is what the Country Party said about Eric Butler. It should be compared with what the honourable member for Parramatta says about Mr Eric Buder whom he invited to address the Young Liberal Movement in Parramatta and does whom he said would inform it on all matters affecting the welfare of young people ern area. The Leader of the Austrahan Country Party, House Mr Douglas Anthony, has condemned the tomorrow. League as disreputable, racist, anti-Semitic and pro-Nazi. I would certainly like to give credit to him and to other members of the Country Party this who have had the courage to speak when so others have long remained silent. At a Ume in of inflation and of economic downturns in the community and of signincant unrest in the community, it is up to those of us in this House who should surely be supporting parliamentary to make it quite clear that we dissociate ourselves from those sorts of people. it is not my fault, I reahse that tomght a disbecause the adjournment debate has been reduced to 20 minutes instead of the usual 30 minutes, the honourable members for Warringah and Parramatta will not be able to reply to op Mr Ruddock- I hope you will not take advanhis long tage of that. is someDr KLUGMAN-No, I will not take advantage of it, but I think it is important, when a sitMr ting member of this Parliament becomes identified with the Immigration Control Association or the National Director of the Australian League of Rights, that it is made clear that he not speak for the whole of his Party. If he does speak for the whole of his Party, that Party in the westdissociates itself from

Speaker: Mr BEAZLEY
Title: ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS UPON NOTICE
text: The answer to the right honourbeen able member's questions is as follows: (a) The cost of professional fees varies from one project to another depending on such factors as(i) the types of professional people involved, e.g. Architects, Structural Engineers, Surveyors Quantity Surveyors, (ii) the level of contract price for the project, (iii) the State in which the Centre is to Nevertheless, the average a child care centre is about 8 per cent of the price. (b) The cost of land for centres varies considerably depending upon how it is obtained, e.g. the land may be provided free, it may be leased basis or it may have situations, there may not be any capital cost. Where land is purchased, the price varies according number of factors, e.g. whether it is in an inner-city area where land is at a premium. Where there has been a charge for land, the cost normally varies about $20,000 to $40,000 actual costs range above and below these amounts. (c) The level of equipment grants for new centres varies depending upon such factors as the number and age range of children to be catered for. In a children aged 2-5 years, equipment grants Child Care Act 1972 would normally be about $9,000. (d) There is no information available on the annual of rental of a 60 child centre. The Child Care Act 1972 does not provide for subsidy in respect of rents. Australia. Commonwealth-owned Land: Municipal Rates (Question No. 569) in Peking restricted to cerMr Snedden asked the Minister for Services to (a) a corridor and Property, upon notice: Great What is the annual revenue foregone by municipalities in respect of rates on Commonwealth-owned land. Mr Daly-The answer to the right honourable s question is as foUows: It is pointed out for the information of therighthonourable member that under Section 114 of the Australian Conthe Australian Government is exempt from any form of municipal rating charges. Therefore, in strict legal terms, the local government authorities have not foregone as they are not legally entitled to anything. However successive Australian Governments have, over the agreed to pay, as an act of grace, the equivalent of municipal rates on housing erected or purchased by the Government solely for domestic purposes, on other property an element for rates is recovered in rents charged to and on Defence Service Homes. Payments are also made for any services rendered by a rating authority such as supply of water, sewerage, electricity or collection of garAustralian Government instrumentalities engaged in enterprise in competition with private organiseither own property or lease property from the Government, pay to the local authority the equivalent of rates assessed on the property. The circumstances in which payments are made by the Australian Government in lieu of rates and whether these have circumstances should be extended can only be considered in the overall context offinancialrelationships between the Australian Government, the State government authorities. In that regard, the Australian Government is very much aware of thefinancialproblems being faced by local government authorities. The Government is giving close attention in developing and implementing its policies, to how best achieve its objectives of having the role of local government become a fuller and more tive one and making available to local government resources adequate for its functions. The Grants Commission Act 1973 incorporates a major with new initiative by the Australian Government designed assist local government. The Act authorises mission to inquire into applications for assistance by regional organisations of local government as approved for this purpose by the Minister for Urban and Regional Development. The Commission's inquiries are being directed towards recommending special assistance for those authorities or regions which arefinanciallydisadvantaged compared other authorities or regions-because tively low rating capacity or requirements not shared by local government generally. The right, honourable member will be aware that the Governsince ment recently announced that it had accepted a recommenGuinea dation by the Grants Commission that grants of $56,345,000 be paid to local government in 1974-75. A precise figure such as that sought by therighthonourattended able member is not readily available. To obtain it would major task involving much time and effort and this does seem to be warranted. In the absence of sufficient tion to do so, I am not prepared to divert resources for such a task. Papua New Guinea: Proposed Purari Hydro-electric Scheme  the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice: 1. Has the Australian Government considered a request from the Papua New Guinea Government for assistance relating to the proposed Purari Hydro-electricity Scheme. 2. If so, can the Minister say whether other have also been approached. 3. What is the Australian Government's attitude. 4. Can the Minister say what reaction has been received from other governments.

Speaker: Mr WHITLAM
Title: ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS UPON NOTICE
text: The Foreign Minister has vided the following answer to the honourable member's question: 1. Yes. The request was for Australian Government participation and assistance in undertaking a detailed technical feasibility study of the Wabo project in the proposed Purari River Hydro-electric Scheme. 2. Yes. Japan. Following a request from the Papua New Guinea Government, the Government of Japan was formally asked on 13 May 1974 to participate and assist, in conjunction with the Australian and Papua New Guinea Governments, in a detailed feasibility study of the Wabo project. 3. The Australian Government is prepared to assist Papua New Guinea with the feasibility study. However, satisfactory arrangements on the allocation of costs and responsibility and on adrninistrative arrangements for the conduct of the study have to be worked out between officials of the Australian, Papua New Guinea and Japanese Governments before the study can commence. 4. The Japanese Government has not yet given a formal Governments and local reaction. Stevedoring Industry (Question No. 706) Mr Malcolm Fraser asked the Minister for governments Labor and Immigration, upon notice: Will he make available the Foster Report on the organisation of the waterfront and any other reports he has in his possession on this subject.

Speaker: Mr CLYDE CAMERON
Title: ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS UPON NOTICE
text: The answer to the prohonourable member's question is as follows: Investigations and studies of various aspects of the stevedoring industry have been and are being carried out by staff of my Department, including Mr N. Foster. When this work has advanced to a stage at which it would be appropriate to make its results generally available, I will inform the Parliament and make arrangements accordingly. Medical and Hospital Contributions (Question No. 855) Dr Klugman asked the Minister for Social Security, upon notice: What was the cost of weekly family subscription to (a) the lowest rate medical benefit funds and (b) hospital funds at (i) public and (ii) intermediate rate, as a percentage of the basic wage and later the minimum weekly wage in New South Wales in (a) 1946, (b) 1949, (c) 1955, (d) 1960, (e) 1965, (0 1970, (g) as at 30 June, 1972 and what is it at present.

Speaker: Mr HAYDEN
Title: ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS UPON NOTICE
text: The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows: Prior to 1 July, 1970, medical benefits organizations operated two or three medical benefits tables which provided varying benefits at varying contribution rates. Since 1 July, 1970, only one medical table has been operated by each organization. These single tables provide more comprehensive insurance cover than was available previously. Consequently the rates of contribution for the tables providing the lowest benefits for the years 1955, 1960 and 1965 are not directly comparable with the tables providing the high rate of benefits available since 1 July 1970. However, the following table medical and hospital contributions charged by the major fund as a percentage of the Federal adult male basic wage and, later, the Federal adult male niinimum weekly wage in New South Wales. The Medical and Hospital Benefits Schemes did not commence until 1953 and, therefore, the years 1946 and 1949 have been excluded. There were no increases in public hospital charges in New South Wales between June 1972 and August 1974. Therefore hospital fund contribution rates remained unchanged and when expressed as percentages of Federal adult male mimmum wage levels, they declined between June, 1972 and August 1974 due to hospital fund contribution rates having remained unchanged during that period. However, as a result of the recent substantial increases in hospital accommodation charges, contribution rate increases can be expected. The date of such increases and the size of the increases for individual hospital funds will depend on the size of the free reserves held by the funds. It is the policy of the Government that excess reserves should be used to the advantage of contributors by keeping the size of contribution increases to a minimum.
