(2) What matters have been discussed. (3) What resolutions have been passed. (4) In particular, on what occasions has the protection of privacy been on the agenda or under discussion, and what conclusions were reached. (5) Will the Attorney-General make available a copy of the report submitted by Professor W. L. Morrison on the law of privacy. (6) What action has the Government taken, what action is it proposing to take, or what proposals are under discussion, in relation to protection of privacy. Mr Enderby-The Attorney-General has prosets out the lowest rates of vided the following answer to the right honourable member's question: (1) 29 and 30 March 1973 (Sydney); 2 and 3 July 1973 (Perth); 19 and 20 February 1974 (Wellington, New Zealand). (2) and (3) The proceedings of the Standing Committee are confidential and the transcript of proceedings which is produced after each meeting bears that classificauon. This is a matter that causes me some concern and I propose to raise it for discussion at the next meeting of the Standing Committee. In the meantime I am able to disclose that in addition to the protection of privacy, dealt with in parts (4) to (6) of the answer to this question, the following matters were considered at the meetings referred to in part (1) of this answer 29 and 30 March 1973 (a) Consumer credit It was decided that a draft bill should be prepared to reflect the recommendations of the Molomby Committee. (b) Pyramid selling Hospital Fund It was decided that the Australian Government would consider introducing legislation, but in the meantime the Public Intermedi- States would proceed with their legislation. Ward ate Ward Coverage (c) Law of domicile It was agreed that the New Zealand Attorney-General contri- would prepare a draft bill to achieve uniform reforms in the bution law. per per week cent (d) Custody The question of reciprocal legislation was considered, 0.41 20c 0.82 aimed at combatting the flaunting of court orders giving cus0.71 40c 1.41 tody of a child to one parent by the other parent taking the 0.95 60c 1.90 child out of the jurisdiction. 1.62 $1.00 2.32 (e) The status of illegitimate children was discussed. 1.54 $1.28 2.47 2 and 3 July 1973 $1.28 1.86 (a) Defamation It was agreed that a study should be undertaken with a view to providing a basis for uniform laws relating to defamation throughout Australia. (b) Law reform bodies It was decided to comnussion a joint study of ways in (Question No. 892) which the work of all law reform bodies throughout Australia could be co-ordinated and assisted. (c) Companies and securities industry The proposal of the Australian Government to introduce legislation m thesefieldswas discussed. (d) Maintenance agreements It was decided that provision should be made in all States and Territories for the registration and enforcement of agreements for maintenance which have been registered in another State or Territory or in New Zealand. (e) Legislative Drafting Institute The possible establishment by the Australian Government of an institute for the training of legislative draftsmen was announced. (0 Foreign adoption orders The recognition of foreign adoption orders was to be examined with a view to obtaining uniformity. (g) Criminal statistics It was decided that the Australian Institute of Criminology should be asked to examine the possibility of achieving uniformity in the method of recording criminal statisucs in Australia. (a) Law of domicile It was decided to examine further a draft bill with a view to reforming the law on a uniform basis. (b) Foreign adoption orders A draft bill on the recognition of foreign adoption orders is to be considered. (c) Commercial arbitration A model bill is to be prepared with a view to updating on uniform basis this branch of the law. (d) Illegitimacy Legislation to remove so far as practicable the legal disabilities of children born out of wedlock was discussed. (4) An item on privacy was on the agenda of the Standing Committee of Attorneys-General at aU three meetings. On the last occasion, Ministers agreed that the protection of privacy was not a subject upon which complete uniformity could be sought and that the details of legislation matter for each jurisdiction. Each Attorney-General has reserved therightto take individual action in this area occasion required. (5) Yes, the repon was tabled 1973. (6) In September 1973 the Attorney-General a Committee of Enquiry into the Protection of Privacy. The purpose of that Committee is Attorney-General on what legislative measures are in the fulfilment of the general right in article 17 of the International itical Rights, with particular reference to: (a) the collection and storage of data concerning individuals by both public especially in thefieldsof (b) the prohibition or regulation of the use of phosidised tographic devices and electronic and recording devices. The Committee has presented a repon on what safeguards ought to be adopted to protect the individual's privacy under the proposed Health Insurance Program. That report was tabled in Parliament in March 1974. The next task of the Committee will be to examine the question of access to personal information recorded by the Depanment of Social Security and what measures are necessary to protect individual privacy in these circumstances. An Ordinance to create a generalrightto privacy in the Australian Capital Territory is being prepared. In addition, clause 19 of the Human Rights Bill 1973 would give effect to article 17 of the International Covenant in Civil and Political Rights, which requires persons to be protected against arbitrary or unlawful interference with their privacy. Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission: Justice Mary Gaudron (Question No. 928) Mr Hunt asked the Minister for Labor and Immigration, upon notice: (1) Has the Minister's attention been drawn to the reponed statement of the Federal Vice President of the Transport Workers' Union, Mr D. Carpenter, in the 'Canberra Times' of 7.8.74, referring to a decision of Justice Mary Gaudron of the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission as a powder-puff decision by a powder-puff judge. 19 and 20 February 1974 (2) If so, what is the attitude of the Minister to this reference to a member of the Commission, and what action does he propose to take against the author of these remarks.

Speaker: Mr CLYDE CAMERON
Title: ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS UPON NOTICE
text: The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows: (1) Yes. (2) The integrity of the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission is in no way demeaned by such statea ments. I understand that the decision of Justice Gaudron was contested in the proper way, by the Transport Workers' Union's lodging an appeal against the decision. That appeal has since been determined by a Full Bench of the Commission. (2) No. Australian Capital Territory: Occasional Care Mr Street asked the Minister for the Capital Territory, upon notice: (1) When is it proposed to commence construction of the permanent Occasional Care Centre to replace the present Occasional Care Centre in Alinga Street, Canberra City. (2) Could the present Occasional Care Centre remain open until the permanent centre is completed without recourse to the use of temporary premises that had been proposed. (3) What Occasional Care Centres are planned for future construction in the Australian Capital Territory. (4) What steps have been taken or are being taken to ensure that there is community participation in the choosing of appropriate sites and the landscaping design of the playground well in advance of the building construction.

Speaker: Mr BRYANT
Title: ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS UPON NOTICE
text: The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows: (1) Afirmprogram has not yet been established for the construction of a permanent Occasional Care Centre, but a site for such a Centre has been identified by the National Capital Development Commission at the intersection of Moore and Rudd Streets, Canberra City. (2) It is not practicable for the existing Occasional Care Centre to continue until the construction of the permanent centre. Construction work on the A.C.T. Health Services Building is scheduled to commence immediately after completion of the temporary occasional care facilities which will be established early in 197S. (3) Occasional Care Centres at Woden (Phillip) and Belconnen are included in the National Capital Development Commission 1974-75 Works Program. Other centres are being planned for new areas. (4) As has been the practice in the past interested community groups will be involved in the siting and planning of new Occasional Care Centres. Cyprus Conflict: Geneva Conventions (QuestionNo. 1095) (Question No. 977) Mr Lloyd asked the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice: 1. Can the Minister confirm a report in the 'Manchester Guardian' that the Turkish Government wrote to the International Red Cross in Geneva renouncing the Geneva Conventions on the rules of war shortly before the attack on Famagusta on 15 August 1974. 2. Can the Minister also confirm that the International Red Cross reminded Turkey of its obUgations as a signatory to the Geneva Convendons on 21 July 1974 the day after the invasion of Cyprus. 3. What steps has the Minister taken to express the abhorrence of the Australian people to any breakdown of the Geneva Conventions by any of the parties to the Cyprus conflict.

Speaker: Mr WHITLAM
Title: ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS UPON NOTICE
text: The Foreign Minister has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question: 1. To the best of our knowledge, the report that the Turkish Government wrote to the International Committee of the Red Cross denouncing the Geneva Conventions is erroneous. We have been advised that no such communiCentres cation was received by the Red Cross from the Turkish (Question No. 991) Government. 2. On 20 July 1974, in accordance with its normal procedures in the event of armed conflict between states, the International Committee of the Red Cross sent messages to Turkey, Greece, the Greek Cypriot authorities and the Turkish Cypriot authorities, reminding them of their obligations under the Geneva Conventions and offering the service of the ICRC as an impartial and objective intermediary for the protection and care of the victims of the conflict. 3. The Australian Government has joined with other members of the Security Council of the United Nations in calling on all parties to the Cyprus conflict to cease all firing and military action and to resume negotiations without delay. Settlement of International Disputes  the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice: What action has been taken by the Government to establish, under United Nation's auspices, a permanent mediation authority to settle (a) border disputes and (b) problems of self-determination since 2 December 1972.

Speaker: Mr WHITLAM
Title: ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS UPON NOTICE
text: The Foreign Minister has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question: The Government has initiated consultations at the United Nations with a view to tabling at the current session of the United Nations General Assembly an appropriate resolution in the general area of the peaceful settlement of international disputes. The Government's intention is to encourage the Assembly to reflect upon the potential "preventive" role of the United Nations in resolving differences and to promote the settlement of international disputes by peaceful measures. There already exist procedures within the United Nations which can be used to settle differences between members over border disputes and problems of self-determination. Their effective use will pend on the willingness of members to resolve their differences in these ways. Australia's objective bly and more generally in the United Nations will be to make these procedures more effective and to bers to turn to them more often. Australian Foreign Affairs Record: Korea  the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice: 1. Was it stated in the Australian April 1974 that, in dealing with the Korean quesuon, Australia's efforts in 1973 ing conciliation and consensus. 2. If so, by what means did Australia contribute (a) to promoting conciliation and(b)to consensus in 1973 and 1974. Advertising agency firm 3. Does the Government consider that recognition of Nonh Korea at this stage will contribute to these ends; if so, how will this be achieved.

Speaker: Mr WHITLAM
Title: ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS UPON NOTICE
text: The Foreign Affairs Minister has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question: 1. The April 1974 Australian Foreign Affairs Record stated that, m dealing with the Korean Question in 1973, Australia's efforts were directed and consensus. 2. (a) and (b). Australia continued to suppon the Joint exerStatement of 4 July 1972, voted for the dissolution of to clear the ground for the two parties themselves work towards unification, played a pan in bringing about the consensus achieved at the 1973 UN General Assembly, spoke to a number of the traditional friends of the DPRK the desirability of their moving some way towards the ROK, and recognised the DPRK. Affairs in consultation with 3. Yes. Recognition of the DPRK, and the subsequent reof ciprocal establishment of Embassies, will promote conciliation and consensus by providing the means for the ready communication of views and by making it plain that each government on the Korean peninsula is regarded as sovereign in its own territory and that therefore, neither has the right to impose unification, which can only be brought about (QuestionNo. 1176) by peaceful discussion between two equal parties. The more widespread the recognition of the DPRK, and the ROK, the are the chances of securing peace and stability in Korea, and of encouraging both panies to negotiate unification through conciliation and consensus. Centres Approved for Recurrent Grant Subsidies (Question No. 243) Mr Snedden asked the Minister for Education, upon notice: What centres are subsidised under the recurrent grants provision of the Child Care Act, where are the centres located, what is the nature of the subsidy and how much does each centre get.

Speaker: Mr BEAZLEY
Title: IUOTO
text: The answer to the right honourUnion of Official Travel Organisable member's question is as follows: The information sought by the right honourable member with regard to the names of those centres approved for recurrent grant subsidies, their location and how much each centre receives is set out hereunder. Therecurrentgrant subsidy as provided for in the Child Care Act is paid on a quarterly basis. The amounts shown in the table are in respect of the January-March 1974 quarter. As provided for in the Child Care Act, the recurrent grant subsidy is paid in respect of certain qualified staff and special need children as denned in the Act. The subsidies vary from quarter to quarter as a result of staff turnover, changes in award rates, fluctuations in attendance patterns including those of children in special need.
